questions.text: A postmenopausal lady came to the clinic with complaints of breast pain and a lump in her right breast for the past 2 months. On examination, the breast appears as shown in the image. What is the most likely cause for this finding?
questions.solution:
In the given image, the orange peel-like appearance, also called as peau d’orange is caused by cutaneous lymphatic edema, due to the obstruction of subcutaneous lymphatics. It is the hallmark of inflammatory carcinoma.

Option A: Infiltration of Cooper’s ligaments leads to dimpling of the skin.

Option C: Infiltration of the lactiferous ducts leads to nipple retraction.

Cancer-en-cuirasse is an aggressive form of cancer, where there is cutaneous and subcutaneous infiltration of the cancer cells.

Note: While Peau d’orange indicates skin involvement, dimpling of the skin and nipple retraction do not indicate skin involvement.

questions.text: A woman came with a 4 x 3 cm lump over the right breast. On examination, the breast appears as shown below. Ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph nodes are palpable with fixed axillary nodes on the left side. What is the most appropriate tumor staging?
questions.solution:
TNM staging in the given scenario is T4d N3c M1. 

  • Tumour of any size with typical skin changes involving > 1/3 of breast- T4d (Inflammatory breast carcinoma)
  • Ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph node involvement - N3c
  • Involvement of any contralateral lymph nodes indicates distant metastasis - M1

Related Pearl: TNM Staging of Carcinoma Breast

Tumor (T)

Description
Tx

Primary tumor cannot be assessed
T0

No evidence of primary tumor
Tis (DCIS) Ductal carcinoma in situ
Tis (Paget) Paget disease not associated with invasive carcinoma or DCIS
T1

≤2 cm in greatest dimension

1mic ≤ 0.1 cm

1a >0.1 to 0.5 cm

1b >0.5 to 1 cm

1c >1 to 2 cm
T2 >2 but ≤5 cm in greatest dimension
T3 >5 cm in greatest dimension
T4

Tumor of any size and -

4a – chest wall involvement (except pectoralis major)# 

4b – skin involvement in the form of ulceration, peau d’orange, satellite nodules  

4c – 4a + 4b  

4d – Inflammatory breast carcinoma (typical skin changes involving >1/3rd of breast)*
Nodes (N) Description
N1 mic Refers to micrometastasis to Lymph node
N1 Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes
N2A Ipsilateral fixed or matted axillary lymph nodes
N2B Ipsilateral internal mammary without axillary lymph node involvement
N3A Ipsilateral infraclavicular lymph nodes
N3B Ipsilateral internal mammary and axillary lymph nodes
N3C Ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph nodes
Distant metastasis (M) Description
M0 Metastasis absent
M1 Metastasis present

 

Stages T, N  M
Stage 0 TisN0 M0
Stage IA T1N0 M0
Stage IB T0,1N1mic M0
Stage IIA T0,1N1 (or) T2N0 M0
Stage IIB T2N1 (or) T3N0 M0
Stage IIIA T0,1,2,3N2 (or) T3N1 M0
Stage IIIB T4 N0,1,2 M0
Stage IIIC

Any T, N3

 M0
Stage IV

Any T, Any N

 M1

# Chest wall includes Serratus anterior, Intercostal muscles, Ribs. Pectoralis muscle is not a part of the chest wall.

* Inflammatory breast carcinoma (stage 4d) is characterized by the skin changes of brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema (peaud’orange) involving >1/3rd of the breast.

Note: LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) is considered a benign condition and not included under Tis.

Prefixes for TNM staging:

  • c: clinical staging (e.g. cT1b)
  • p: pathological (histological) staging
  • y: stage following systemic or radiation therapy (either prior to surgery or as a primary treatment)
  • r: staging at the time of retreatment or recurrence for disease progression

Suffix for TNM staging:

  • m: multiple primary tumours of the same histology in the same organ, e.g. T2(m) or T2(5), the latter meaning that there are five primary tumours

questions.text: What is the recommended age for starting screening mammography?
questions.solution:
The recommended age for women to start annual screening mammography is 40 years of age.

  • Until 44 years of age, it is her individual choice to decide on whether she wants screening mammography or not.
  • For ages between 45 and 49 years, it is mandatory to get annual breast screening done.
  • After the age of 50 years, it is advised that women get a second yearly screening done.

October is the Breast Cancer Awareness Month across the world. It helps to increase attention and support for the awareness, early detection, and treatment as well as palliative care of this disease.

Related Pearl: Breast Cancer Screening

Breast Cancer Screening

Individuals are encouraged to conduct a risk assessment by 25 years of age. This helps classify them into average risk or increased risk groups.

Recommendations: 

  1. Average-risk (no known genetic or family history of breast cancer)
    • 25-39 years of age: clinical breast examination every 1-3 years; 
    • ≥ 40 years of age: clinical breast examination and mammogram annually
  2. High-risk (positive family or genetic history of breast cancer)
    • Consult a healthcare professional every 6-12 months after 21 years of age
    • Annual mammogram or MRI from 25 years of age or 10 years prior to the age at which the youngest family member was diagnosed with breast cancer (whichever is earliest)
  3. Asymptomatic women with previously treated breast cancer
    • Consult a healthcare professional every 6-12 months
    • Annual mammogram
    • Annual MRI to be considered
  4. Mammogram and USG are not contraindicated in pregnant and breastfeeding women

High-risk patients for breast cancer:

  1. Women (or a first-degree relative) with a known BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation or TP53 or PTEN genes
  2. Two first-degree relatives with breast cancers with or without gene mutations
  3. Women with a history of chest irradiation between the ages of 10 and 30
  4. Women with previously biopsy-proven breast cancer
  5. Women with ≥ 20% lifetime risk for breast cancer based on breast cancer risk models

*According to NCCN 2022 guidelines

questions.text: The most common functional enteropancreatic tumour in MEN 1:
questions.solution:
The most common functional tumour is gastrinoma followed by insulinoma.

MEN 1 syndrome endocrine and non endocrine components:

  • Most common enteropancreatic tumor is Gastrinoma followed by insulinoma.
  • Other tumors that are seen are VIPoma, Glucagonoma.
Endocrine features Non endocrine features
Parathyroid adenoma (90%) Lipomas(30%)

Entero pancreatic tumour (30-70%)

Gastrinoma (>50%)

Insulinoma (10-30%)

Glucagonoma(<3%)

VIPoma(<1%)

Somatostatinoma (2%)

 Facial angiofibromas (85%)

Foregut carcinoid

Gastric enterochromaffin like tumour NF (10%)

Thyroid and Bronchial carcinoid NF (2%)

 Collagenomas(70%)

Anterior pituitary tumour(20-70%)

Prolactinoma (60%)

Somatotroph inoma (25%)

Corticotropinoma (<5%)

Nonfunctioning (<5%)

 Pheochromocytoma (<1%)
Adrenal cortex NF (25%) Ependymoma   (<1%)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding congenital diaphragmatic hernia?

choices.text: Most CDH defects occur on the left side
Occurs due to failure of closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal in the developing fetus
Pulmonary hypoplasia and pulmonary hypertension significantly affects the prognosis
The posterolateral variant of this hernia is known as Morgagni hernia

questions.solution:
The posterolateral variant of congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is known as Bochdalek hernia while the anteromedian variant is called Morgagni hernia.

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia results from the failure of closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal in the developing fetus.

Typically in CDH, there is a left-sided posterolateral diaphragmatic defect allowing herniation of abdominal viscera into the chest. 80% of CDH develops on the left side.

The following sequence of events in CDH leads to the development of pulmonary hypoplasia.

Pulmonary hypertension and pulmonary hypoplasia are the most important prognostic factors in congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

Other poor prognostic indicators in CDH :

  • The presence of liver in the thoracic cavity 
  • Early respiratory distress, within 24 h after birth
  • Need for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation
  • Herniation to the contralateral lung (right-sided hernia)
  •  

Treatment of congenital diaphragmatic hernia:

Variable period of time (24-72 hours) is to be allowed for stabilization before surgical repair. Immediate respiratory support should be provided, including rapid endotracheal intubation and sedation. 

Bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated in newborns with congenital diaphragmatic hernia because it causes distension of the stomach which in turn may limit the expansion of the already hypoplastic lung.

During surgery, the viscera are reduced into the abdominal cavity, and the posterolateral defect in the diaphragm is closed using interrupted, nonabsorbable sutures. In most cases (80%-90%), a hernia sac is not present. If identified, it is excised at the time of repair.

Related Pearl: Congenital diaphragmatic hernias (CDH)

It is due to the failure of the closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal in the developing fetus (Normally the pleuroperitoneal cavities separate by 8-10 weeks of gestation). Left-sided hernias are more common(80%).

The two well-recognized congenital sites where abdominal viscera can herniate into the chest are:

  • The foramen of Morgagni: a hernia in the anteromedial part of the diaphragm with a defect between the sternal and costal attachments. The most commonly involved viscus is the transverse colon.
  • The foramen of Bochdalek: through the dome of the diaphragm posterolaterally

CDH causes pulmonary hypoplasia (bilateral) by compressing the developing lung. These lungs have smaller bronchi, with less bronchial branching and less alveolar surface area than lungs in normal infants. Pulmonary hypertension may also develop due to increased thickness of arteriolar smooth muscle and also by multiple local and systemic vasoactive factors.

Clinical features:

  • respiratory distress at birth
  • grunting respiration
  • chest retractions
  • dyspnea
  • cyanosis
  • scaphoid abdomen
  • decreased breath sounds along with bowel sound over the chest with CDH
  • shifting of heart sounds to the right (for left-sided CDH)

questions.text: A patient with hematemesis was brought to the Emergency. His BP was 90/60 mm of Hg and pulse was 110. A gastro-oesophageal bleed is suspected and the given tube is inserted for tamponade. Identify the tube.
questions.solution:
The given tube is a Minnesota tube.

Minnesota tube has 4 openings – 2 suction tubes and 2 inflation tubes. Suction tubes allow aspiration of both gastric and oesophageal contents.

Sengstaken-Blakemore tube has 3 lumens. It has ports for gastric and esophageal balloons and a gastric aspiration port.

The Minnesota tube or modified-Sengstaken Blakemore tube has an additional oesophageal aspiration port.

questions.text: The peripheral vascular resistance is decreased in ____________
questions.solution:
The peripheral vascular resistance is decreased in distributive shock.

It is the condition of reduced oxygen delivery where the primary physiologic disturbance is a reduction in systemic vascular resistance. It is unique among the types of shock in that there is a compensatory increase in cardiac output. The most common cause of distributive shock is sepsis.

The causes of vasodilatation in various types of distributive shock:

Type of distributive shock  Cause of vasodilatation 
Septic shock  Release of bacterial products (endotoxin) and the activation of cellular and humoral components of the immune system. 
Anaphylactic shock  Histamine release 
Neurogenic shock (spinal cord injury)  Failure of sympathetic outflow and adequate vascular tone 

The following Table shows cardiovascular and metabolic characteristics of different types of shock.

  Hypovolemia Cardiogenic Obstructive Distributive
Cardiac output Low Low Low

High (in septic and anaphylactic shock)

Low (in neurogenic shock)
Vascular resistance High High High Low
Venous pressure Low High High Low
Mixed venous saturation Low Low Low High
Base deficit High High High High

questions.text: Which dietary component is lacking in patients started on TPN?
questions.solution:
Fibers are not included in total parenteral nutrition.

Total enteral or parenteral nutrition necessitates the provision of the macronutrients, carbohydrates, fat and protein, together with vitamins, trace elements, electrolytes, and water.

questions.text: What does the finding depicted in the image signify?
questions.solution:
The image shows Hutchinsons's nail sign in subungual melanoma. It arises from the nail matrix, most commonly in the great toe or thumb.

Hutchinson's nail sign is an important clinical clue to subungual melanoma. It is characterized by the extension of brown or black pigment from the nail bed, matrix, and nail plate to the adjacent cuticle and proximal or lateral nail folds. It is also associated with nail dystrophy. 

Note: Pseudo-Hutchison’s sign is a reflection of the pigmentation of the nail bed and nail matrix through the transparent nail folds. 

Option A: Subungal hematoma is a close differential of subungual melanoma. It is seen secondary to trauma which causes bleeding and resultant hematoma formation and pigmentation. It is important to note that the features of Hutchinson's nail sign are not seen with subungual hematoma.

Option B: Nodular melanoma is a condition where malignant melanoma cells proliferate downwards through the skin – this is known as vertical growth. The lesion presents as a nodule that has been rapidly enlarging.

Option D: Lentigo maligna is an early form of melanoma, in which the malignant cells are confined to the tissue of origin, the epidermis, hence it is often reported as in-situ melanoma.

Note: Subungual melanoma can be either superficial spreading melanoma or acral lentiginous melanoma. A difference of opinion has been noted in Bailey and Love, 27th ed. where it has been mentioned that melanoma under the fingernail is usually superficial spreading melanoma. However, most dermatology textbooks including the Rooks 9th ed. and Fitzpatrick's 9th ed and several research articles mentioned subungual melanoma as a variant of acral lentiginous melanoma.

questions.text: A patient has presented to you with a burn wound as seen in the image below. With regards to Jackson's zones of tissue injury, which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Area 2 is the most severely burned portion
The outer area of a burn is called the zone of hyperemia
Vasodilation is seen in the area 3
Area 1 heals with minimal or no scarring

questions.solution:
Vasoconstriction (not vasodilation) is seen in red region or zone of stasis (marked zone 3).

Jackson zones of tissue injury following burns has three zones:

  • The zone of coagulation is the most severely burned portion and is typically in the center of the wound.
  • Peripheral to that is a zone of stasis, with variable degrees of vasoconstriction and resultant ischemia.
  • The last, outermost area of a burn is called the zone of hyperemia, which will heal with minimal or no scarring and is most like a superficial or first-degree burn. It is characterized by vasodilation from inflammation surrounding the burn wound.

questions.text: A child with a grazed knee comes to your clinic for first aid. He has a history of nephrotic syndrome and is on oral prednisolone therapy. Which stage of wound healing would be most affected by his medication?
questions.solution:
While all of the given options are inhibited by steroids, the major effect of steroids is to inhibit the initial inflammatory phase of wound healing (angiogenesis, neutrophil and macrophage migration, and fibroblast proliferation) and the release of lysosomal enzymes.

The stronger the anti-inflammatory effect of the steroid compound used, the greater the inhibitory effect on wound healing. Steroids used after the first 3 to 4 days post-injury do not affect wound healing as severely as when they are used in the immediate postoperative period. 

In addition to inhibiting collagen synthesis, steroids also inhibit epithelialization and contraction and contribute to increased rates of wound infection, regardless of the time of administration.

Steroid delayed healing of cutaneous wounds can be stimulated to epithelialize by topical application of vitamin A.

questions.text: The most common cause of skin graft failure is ____

choices.text: Poor quality of the recipient bed

questions.solution:
The most common cause of skin graft failure is hematoma under the graft, where the blood clot is a barrier to contact of the graft and bed for revascularization.

Other causes are shearing or movement of the graft on the bed, infection, poor quality of the recipient bed, and characteristics of the graft itself, such as thickness or vascularity of the donor site.

Related Pearl: Skin Grafting : Phases of Graft Uptake

Skin graft uptake occurs in three phases:

  1. Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): During the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from the host bed capillaries.
  2. Inosculation: Cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses.
  3. Neovascularization: Blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft.

Sensations return to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, followed by light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: Some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition, revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced with fibroblasts by day 7).

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the casualty with complaints of recurrent episodes of syncope and cramping of his left arm. Symptoms mostly occur during his evening badminton practice sessions.  Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: Due to occlusion in the 3rd part of subclavian artery
Distal pulse of the affected side is feeble
CT angiography is used to visualize retrograde blood flow

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of subclavian steal syndrome. In subclavian steal syndrome, the first part of the subclavian artery is occluded.

Subclavian steal syndrome is characterized by the presence of stenosis in the first part of the subclavian artery either due to atherosclerotic changes or emboli. It leads to reversed flow in the vertebral artery causing cerebral ischemia.

Symptoms include dizziness, syncope on arm exercise. Occasionally, distal pulses in the arm of the affected side are found to be feeble.

Investigations include duplex ultrasonography, CT, and MR angiography.

It can be treated by angioplasty, stenting or by extra-thoracic subclavian bypass.

questions.text: A 42-year-old  daily wage laborer comes to you with discoloration of her legs. She was diagnosed with varicose veins 5 years ago which was left untreated. Identify the feature given in the picture.
questions.solution:
Atrophia blanche is localised white atrophic skin frequently surrounded by dilated capillaries and hyperpigmentation, usually seen around the ankles. This is a sign of chronic venous disease.

Lipodermatosclerosis is changes in the skin of the lower legs due to chronic venous insufficiency. It is a form of panniculitis (inflammation of the layer of fat under the skin). There is swelling and a tapering of the legs above the ankles, leading to 'inverted champagne bottle' appearance.

 

Corona phlebectatica are fan-shaped patterns of small intradermal veins on the medial or lateral aspects of the ankle or foot. It is also called ankle flare or malleolar flare. It is an early sign of advanced venous disease.

Related Pearl: CEAP Classification of Chronic Lower Extremity Venous Disease

CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology)

Clinical classification (C)*

C0

No visible or palpable signs of venous disease

C1

Telangiectases or reticular veins

C2

C2r

Varicose veins

Recurrent varicose veins

C3

Edema

C4

Changes in skin and subcutaneous tissue secondary

to chronic venous disease

C4a-Pigmentation or eczema

C4b-Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche

C4c-Corona phlebectatica

C5

Healed ulcer

C6

C6r

Active ulcer

Recurrent active venous ulcer

S

With symptoms attributable to venous disease

A

Absence of symptoms attributable to venous disease

Etiological classification (E)

Ec

Congenital (Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome)

Ep

Primary

Es

Secondary (postthrombotic syndrome, trauma)

Esi

Secondary (intravenous)

Ese

Secondary (extravenous)

Ec

Congenital

En

No venous cause identified

Anatomic classification (A)

As

Superficial

Ad

Deep

Ap

Perforator

An

No venous location identified

Patho-physiologic classification (P)

Pr

Reflux

Po

Obstruction, thrombosis

Pr,o

Reflux and obstruction

Pn

No venous pathophysiology identified

Note:

  • The descriptor A (asymptomatic) or S (symptomatic) is placed after the C clinical class.
  • Telengiactesia refers to tiny intradermal venules <1 mm in diameter.
  • Reticular veins refer to small dilated subdermal blue veins of 1 to 2.9 mm
  • Varicose veins refer to dilated tortuous veins >3 mm in diameter

questions.text:
A 50-year-old patient on DOTS therapy was rushed to the casualty after having massive hemoptysis. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

DOTS- Directly Observed Therapy Short Course

choices.text: Intubation is done into the non-bleeding lung.
Massive hemoptysis is defined as expectoration of over 750 mL of blood within 24-hours.
Presence of significant cavitary disease is an indication for urgent surgery.
Bleeding is most likely due to pulmonary artery erosion.

questions.solution:
Massive hemoptysis is defined as the expectoration of over 600 mL of blood within a 24-hour period. Common causes include tuberculosis, bronchiectasis, and cancer. It is a medical emergency.

Any hemoptysis that can cause airway compromise or lead to hemodynamic collapse is called massive hemoptysis. This includes blood loss of >600mL/24h or >150ml/h which can flood the anatomical dead space of the lung.

Bleeding can either be from the bronchial artery circulation (most common) or from the pulmonary artery circulation. Bleeding from cavitary lesions is due to pulmonary artery erosion.

The chest X-ray is the first investigation followed by rigid or flexible bronchoscopy.

The cause of death in massive hemoptysis is usually due to asphyxiation (rather than blood loss itself). This is why airway stabilization by intubating into the non-bleeding lung is the priority. After ventilation is achieved, the bleeding site should be identified using bronchoscopy. Bleeding is controlled by laser, bronchial occlusion, or arterial embolization. Surgical resection of the involved area is also done in some cases.

Indications for urgent surgical intervention for massive hemoptysis:

  • Presence of a fungus ball
  • Presence of a lung abscess
  • Presence of significant cavitary disease
  • Failure to control the bleeding.

questions.text: An elderly woman presents with recent onset facial asymmetry and a lump over the roof of the mouth for the past 1 year. On examination, a solitary erythematous swelling with diffuse borders is seen over the left hard palate. Biopsy of the lesion reveals a swiss cheese pattern. Which of the following conditions is she likely to have?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and biopsy finding is suggestive of adenoid cystic carcinoma.  Facial asymmetry points to the perineural invasion of the tumor into the facial nerve, which is characteristic of adenoid cystic carcinoma.

It is the second most common malignant tumor of the parotid gland. It is a slow-growing tumor most commonly involving the parotid and submandibular glands. Histology shows a swiss cheese pattern. The tubular type has the best prognosis, while the solid type has the worst. 

It has a deceptively benign histologic appearance characterized by indolent, locally invasive growth with a high propensity for local recurrence and distant metastasis. The most common site of distant metastasis is the lung. Treatment involves removal of the gross tumor, with radiation therapy for the microscopic disease.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: A 26-year-old formula one driver was rushed to the casualty, unconscious, following a heavy crash from a side-impact collision during a racing event. The CT scan was normal. However, MRI showed multiple small hemorrhages, especially in the corpus callosum and the dorsolateral midbrain, with no midline shift. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a normal CT and MRI showing evidence of hemorrhages in the corpus callosum and midbrain is probably due to a diffuse axonal injury.

A diffuse axonal injury is a form of primary brain injury seen in high-energy accidents. It is caused by damage to axons throughout the brain due to rotational acceleration and then deceleration. Axons may be completely disrupted and then retract, forming axon balls.

Small hemorrhages can be seen in more severe cases, especially on MRI (investigation of choice). Hemorrhage is classically seen in the corpus callosum and the dorsolateral midbrain. The prognosis is very poor.

MRI showing multiple hypointense punctate foci within the subcortical and deep white matter within the corpus callosum is characteristic of diffuse axonal injury.

Related Pearl: Diffuse Axonal Injury

The mechanism of diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is primarily a non-impact rotational acceleration-deceleration injury. This leads to the deformation of the axons by stretching them.

Pathology of DAI:

  • Changes in permeability of the axolemma
  • Axonal swelling
  • Intracellular calcium accumulation
  • Proteolysis
  • The collapse of the cytoskeleton
  • 'Retraction balls or globes' - bulbous and clubbed axons. Seen earliest at 12-18 hours. The number of retraction balls begins to decrease after 2-3 weeks after injury and a cluster of microglial cells appears followed by astrocytosis and demyelination.
  • Immuno-histochemistry shows beta-amyloid precursor protein - the most reliable indicator of axon damage. Seen earliest at 2-3 hours. 

Image shows scattered axonal retraction balls stained with Congo Red:

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of crushing chest pain radiating to the jaw and dysphagia. It starts whenever he has ice cream and he takes sublingual nitroglycerin which provides him relief. He underwent manometry which showed simultaneous multi-peaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mm Hg). What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with episodes triggered by cold foods and manometric findings are suggestive of a diffuse esophageal spasm (DES).

Diffuse esophageal spasm is a hypermotility disorder of the esophagus. It is caused by spontaneous, abnormal contractions seen more in the distal two-thirds of the esophageal body. It is more common in women. 

Patients usually present with dysphagia and chest pain. Pathologically, there is marked hypertrophy of the circular muscles. It is often triggered by cold foods. It mimics symptoms of myocardial infarction and also shows improvement when sublingual nitroglycerin is administered. It causes smooth muscle relaxation of the esophagus. 

A barium swallow shows a corkscrew esophagus. However, manometry (high-resolution manometry is preferred) is the gold standard test for diagnosis. In classic manometry, if there are simultaneous, multi-peaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mmHg) or long duration (>2.5 seconds) it is suggestive of diffuse esophageal spasm.

On high-resolution manometry, a DCI (distal contractile integral) >450 mmHg is suggestive of DES. The distal contractile integral (DCI) is an index of contractile vigor in high-resolution manometry, calculated as the product of amplitude, duration, and span of the distal esophageal contraction.

Hypertensive lower esophageal sphincter - It is achalasia in evolution. Shows increased LES pressure but normal peristalsis.

Nutcracker’s esophagus - In conventional manometry, it shows a high-amplitude peristaltic contraction ( >180mmHg) and a longer duration of contraction (>7sec).

In high-resolution manometry, a DCI > 8000mmHg is suggestive of nutcracker's esophagus.

Related Pearl: Manometric classification of esophageal motility disorders

Types Definition
Disorders of EGJ obstruction
Type I achalasia
(classic)		 Abnormal IRP
100% failed peristalsis
Type II
(with panesophageal pressurization)		 Abnormal IRP
100% failed peristalsis
Panesophageal pressurization
Type III
(spastic)		 Abnormal IRP
100% failed peristalsis
Spastic contractions
Panesophageal pressurization or normal presurization
DCI > 450mmHg
Disorders of peristalsis 
DES (Diffuse esophageal spasm) Normal IRPN
Non-peristaltic (spastic) contractions or premature contractions.
DCI>450mmHg
Nutcracker’s esophagus Normal IRP
Increased duration of peristalsis
Normal peristalsis
DCI>8000mmHg

DCI (distal contractile integral) is an index of contractile vigor and is calculated as the product of amplitude, duration, and span of the distal esophageal contraction, (mmHg·s·cm).

IRP (integrated relaxation pressure) corresponds to the mean pressure of greatest post deglutitive relaxation in a 10 seconds gap, triggered at the beginning of a swallow, (mmHg).

questions.text: A woman presented to the gastroenterology OPD with significant weight loss, fatigue, and a bloating sensation for the past 8 months. A detailed workup was done, and she was diagnosed with early gastric carcinoma. All of the following structures can be involved in this stage except:
questions.solution:
In early gastric cancer, there is no involvement of muscularis propria.

Gastric cancer can be classified as early and advanced gastric cancer, based on the extent of involvement. 

Early gastric cancer involves:

  1. Mucosa (including muscularis mucosa)
  2. Submucosa
  3. +/- lymph nodes

Advanced gastric cancer involves:

  1. Muscularis layer
  2. +/- adjacent structures

questions.text: What is the rate of recurrent ulceration in patients undergoing the procedure shown below?
questions.solution:
The picture depicts Highly Selective Vagotomy (HSV). The rate of recurrent ulceration after HSV is 2–10%.

In HSV, the vagal nerve supply to the proximal two-thirds of the stomach is severed where all the parietal cells are located. The nerve supply to the antrum and pylorus is preserved. The nerve of Laterjet is spared.

Surgery

Recurrent ulceration rate

Gastrectomy

1–4%

Gastroenterostomy alone

50%

Truncal vagotomy and drainage

2–7%

Selective vagotomy and drainage

5–10%

HSV

2–10%

Truncal vagotomy and antrectomy

1%

Note: Vagal nerves are motor to the stomach and denervation of the antro-pyloro-duodenal segment results in gastric stasis after truncal vagotomy. Hence, a drainage procedure, most commonly Heineke–Mikulicz pyloroplasty, is done along with vagotomy.

questions.text: Which type of hernia is depicted in the following diagram?
questions.solution:
The diagram shows Maydl’s hernia/Hernia-en-W/retrograde hernia, where 2 loops of the bowel remain in the hernia sac with the connecting loop inside the abdomen.

Option A: In Richter's hernia, a small portion of the antimesenteric wall of the intestine is trapped within the hernia. Strangulation can occur without the pres­ence of intestinal obstruction. Clinically, it mimics gastroenteritis.

Option B: In Littre’s hernia, Meckel’s diverticulum is the content. Amyand’s hernia is an inguinal hernia in which the hernia sac contains a normal or acutely inflamed appendix.

Option C: Petersen hernia is caused by the herniation of intestinal loops through the defect between the small bowel limbs, the transverse mesocolon, and the retroperitoneum, after any type of gastrojejunostomy.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman underwent an open repair of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The procedure was uneventful. However, on the 2nd postoperative day, the patient developed symptoms of acute abdomen and bloody diarrhea with significant guarding. The patient was taken up for an exploratory laparotomy. Which of the following areas is most likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of ischemic colitis and it occurs most commonly at the splenic flexure.

Ischemic colitis occurs due to interruption or decrease in colonic blood flow. It may occur with many different conditions, including embolism from cardiac disease, low-flow states such as congestive heart failure, sepsis, and vasopressor use. Major vascular surgery (both open and endovascular repair), especially involving the abdominal aorta, is a well-known risk factor for developing ischemic colitis.

Although any area of the colon may be affected, the watershed areas of the splenic flexure (Griffith’s point) and the rectosigmoid (Sudeck’s point) are the most prone to ischemia because of the often incomplete anastomoses of the marginal artery in these locations. The next most common area afflicted is the cecum, secondary to low blood flow in the terminal branches of the ileocolic artery.

Splenic flexure (also known as Griffith's point) is a watershed area between the superior and inferior mesenteric arteries.

Sudeck point is a watershed area between the sigmoid arterial branch from the inferior mesenteric artery and the superior rectal artery (branch of Inferior mesentric artery).

The marginal artery of Drummond runs parallel to the colon, connecting the SMA and IMA circulation - the majority of blood flow to the left and sigmoid colon in case of occlusion of the IMA.

Arc of Riolan is a variable collateral vessel that connects the SMA (middle colic vessel) to the IMA (left colic).

questions.text: During a colonoscopy on a 58-year-old female patient, a smooth nodular polyp is found and excised. The microscopic image is given. Choose the incorrect statement regarding the polyp.

choices.text: Usually seen in the 6th and 7th decade of life
Malignant transformation takes place within 5 years

questions.solution:
Hyperplastic polyps, as seen in the histological picture, do not have malignant potential.  

Elongated crypts, i.e., serrated (saw-toothed) or star-shaped appearance, is a characteristic feature of a hyperplastic polyp.

They are the most common type of colorectal polyps and are usually seen in the 6th and 7th decade of life. More than 90% occur in rectosigmoid region.

questions.text: Identify the incision made on a patient while performing an appendicectomy.
questions.solution:
Lanz incision is a transverse skin crease incision for appendicitis 2 cm below the  umbilicus, centered on the midclavicular–mid inguinal line

Option A: Gridiron incision is an oblique muscle-splitting incision in the right lower quadrant. It is also called McBurney incision.

Option C: Rutherford–Morrison incision is an oblique muscle-cutting incision with its lower end over McBurney’s point and extending obliquely upwards and laterally as necessary(Shown on the left side in the image for the sake of clarity)

Option D: Rockey–Davis incision is a transverse right lower quadrant incision.

questions.text:
Match the following radiological signs in intestinal tuberculosis with their respective appearance:
Sign Appearance
1. Sterlein sign A. Thickening of the valve lips, with narrowing of the terminal ileum
2. Gooseneck deformity B. Loss of ileocecal angle with dilated terminal ileum
3. String sign C. Narrowing of the terminal ileum with a shortened cecum
4. Fleischner sign  D. A persistent narrow stream of barium
questions.solution:
The correctly matched option is 1 - C, 2 - B, 3 - D, 4 - A.

Sign Appearance
Sterlein sign

Narrowing of the terminal ileum with a shortened cecum
Gooseneck deformity Loss of ileocecal angle with dilated terminal ileum
String sign A persistent narrow stream of barium 
Fleischner sign  Thickening of the valve lips, with narrowing of the terminal ileum

Related Pearl: Barium studies in GI tuberculosis

  • Earliest feature is spasm and hypermotility, with edema of the valve.
  • Thickening of the valve lips, with narrowing of the terminal ileum: Fleischner or inverted umbrella sign is characteristic of TB.
  • In advance disease, the characteristic deformity includes symmetric, annular, napkin-ring stenosis and obstruction or shortening and pouch formation.
  • The cecum is shrunken and retracts out of the iliac fossa due to contraction of the mesocolon: Pulled-up cecum
  • Loss of ileocecal angle with dilated terminal ileum: Gooseneck deformity
  • Narrowing of the terminal ileum due to irritability, along with shortened rigid cecum: Sterlein sign
  • Persistent narrow stream of barium in the bowel indicates stenosis: String sign

questions.text: All are true about Meckel's diverticulum, except:

choices.text: It arises from the anti-mesenteric border of ileum.
If incidentally detected, it should always be treated conservatively.

questions.solution:
Conservative management is not the only treatment for an incidentally detected Meckel's diverticulum. 

Meckel’s diverticulum is caused by a failure of normal regression of the vitelline duct that develops during weeks 5 to 7 of gestation. It arises from the anti-mesenteric border of the ileum. Since all 3 layers of the bowel wall (mucosa, submucosa, and muscularis propria) are present, it is a true diverticulum.

When Meckel's diverticulum is found in the course of abdominal surgery,

  • In cases of narrow-mouthed, thickened Meckel’s diverticulum, resection of the diverticulum is the treatment of choice.
  • If it has a wide mouth and is not thickened, it can safely be left alone. 

Related Pearl: Rule of two’s in Meckel's diverticulum

  • 2% prevalence
  • 2:1 male predominance
  • Located approx 2 feet (60 cm) proximal to the ileocecal valve in adults
  • Approx 2 inches in length
  • Half of those who are symptomatic are under 2 years of age.
  • 2 types of heterotopic mucosa (gastric & pancreatic)

questions.text: Which type of anal fistula is seen in this image?
questions.solution:
In the given image, the fistula traverses the internal sphincter and tracks down the space between the internal and external anal sphincters. Hence, it is an inter-sphincteric type of anal fistula. It is the most common anal fistula.

A fistula-in-ano is an epithelial-lined tract connecting the anal canal to the perianal skin. Patients usually complain of intermittent purulent discharge and pain. Anal fistulas can be simplex or complex fistulas.

  1. Simple fistulas- include a single tract, subcutaneous tract, and those that involve less than 30% of the external sphincter. They are easier to treat, and have lower chances of recurrence. 
  2. Complex fistulas- include fistulas involving more than 30% of the external sphincter, with multiple tracts, recurrent fistulas, and those associated with other predisposing factors, such as Crohn disease and radiation treatment.

Fistulas can also be classified into high or low-lying fistulas, based on their location with respect to the puborectalis muscle.

Related Pearl: Park's classification of fistula–in–ano

 Type of Fistula

Arises due to 

Begins from

Track

Ends in

Inter-sphincteric

Perianal abscess

Dentate line

In inter-sphincteric space

Perianal skin or perineum

Trans- sphincteric

Ischiorectal Fossa abscess

Dentate line

Crosses the internal and external sphincters 

Perineal skin or perineum

Supra- sphincteric

Supra-levator abscess

Dentate line

Penetrates the inter-sphincteric space, continues above puborectalis, and penetrates levator ani

Perineal skin or perineum

Extra- sphincteric

Penetrating injury

Crohn’s disease

Carcinoma rectum

 Rectum or sigmoid colon 

Outside the external sphincter, penetrating the levator ani 

 Peri-anal skin via ischio-rectal  fossa.

questions.text: Delorme procedure is used for treating patients with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Delorme procedure is used in the treatment of rectal prolapse. It involves mucosal stripping and muscle plication of the rectal prolapse using interrupted sutures. It is performed externally under regional or general anesthesia.

Rectal prolapse occurs when a mucosal or full-thickness layer of rectal tissue protrudes through the anal orifice. Surgical management includes:

Perineal approach-

  • Thiersch operation- a steel wire, or silas-tic or nylon tape, is placed around the anal canal. Largely obsolete now due to problems with chronic perineal sepsis, anal stenosis, and obstructed defaecation
  • Delorme's operation
  • Altemeier's procedure- involves removal of the prolapsed rectum and associated sigmoid colon, followed by which a coloanal anastomosis is created. It is often complicated by poor bowel control with fecal soiling secondary to the loss of rectal reservoir.

The advantages of a perineal approach include minimal postoperative pain, early mobility, and low levels of morbidity. However, given the higher recurrence rates, it is best reserved for patients at a higher risk of developing complications post major surgeries.

Abdominal approach- 

  • Suture rectopexy
  • Resection rectopexy
  • Mesh rectopexy

The principle of all abdominal operations for rectal prolapse is to fix the rectum in its normal anatomical position.

questions.text: Which of the following chemotherapy regimens is used for treating patients with rectal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
5-Fluorouracil-based regimens with leucovorin and oxaliplatin (FOLFOX) reduce recurrence and improve survival in patients with colorectal carcinoma.

Irinotecan (FOLFIRI regimen) is also used as a second-line chemotherapy agent. Adjuvant chemotherapy is routinely recommended in patients with lymph node involvement.

Option B: ABVD regimen is used for Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Option C: RCHOP regimen is used for B-cell Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Option D: MVAC regimen is used for advanced bladder carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Chemotherapy for GI Tumours

GI malignancy

Chemotherapy

Esophageal carcinoma

ECF (Epirubicin + Cisplatin + 5-FU)

Gastric carcinoma

ECF (Epirubicin + Cisplatin + 5-FU)

Small intestine adenocarcinoma

5-FU

Colorectal carcinoma

FOLFOX-IV (5-FU + Leucovorin + Oxaliplatin)

Carcinoma of the anal canal

Nigro Regimen: Chemoradiation (5-FU + Mitomycin C) + Radiation

questions.text: A 24-year-old professional football player was tackled hard during a match. He complains of severe pain in the left upper abdomen. On examination, his BP is 100/74 mm Hg and there is tenderness and crepitus over the left 10th and 11th ribs. He also complains of pain over the left shoulder when pressure is applied over the left upper abdominal quadrant. This sign is called:
questions.solution:
Kehr sign refers to referred pain in the tip of the left shoulder when firm pressure is applied over the left upper quadrant. It is also elicited by raising the left leg.

It is seen in the case of hemoperitoneum, especially due to splenic injury. It occurs due to the collection of blood below the diaphragm and irritation of the phrenic nerve. 

Option A: Ballance sign is also seen in splenic injury. It is an area of percussive dullness in the left upper quadrant due to the coagulation of blood from the injured spleen.

Option B: Cullen sign refers to periumbilical bruising in cases of hemoperitoneum, especially those of pancreatic origin. 

Option D: Grey Turner sign refers to bluish discolouration around flanks in case of hemoperitoneum especially acute hemorrhagic pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the OPD with a skin lesion as shown in the image below. The lesions were initially small but have now spread to the entire limb and the abdomen. She has a history of long-standing diabetes and recurrent episodes of deep vein thrombosis despite anticoagulation therapy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image depicts necrolytic migratory erythema. This skin lesion along with a history of long-standing diabetes and recurrent deep vein thrombosis is suggestive of glucagonoma.

Related Pearl: Clinical features of glucaganoma: 4Ds

  • Diabetes – usually mild and not associated with ketoacidosis
  • Dermatitis – Necrolytic erythema migrans
  • Deep vein thrombosis
  • Depression

Related Pearl: Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms

Endocrine neoplasm

Clinical features

Glucagonoma

Mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia

Insulinoma

Clinically significant hypoglycemia

Gastrinoma

Peptic ulceration often unresponsive to therapy and in unusual locations such as the jejunum

Somatostatinoma

Diabetes mellitus, cholelithiasis, steatorrhea, and hypochlorhydria

VIPoma

Watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria, or WDHA syndrome

Pancreatic polypeptide-secreting endocrine tumors

Present as mass lesions as even high plasma levels of this hormone fail to cause symptoms

Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.

In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

questions.text: The following image shows the retrograde ureteropyelogram of a patient with loin pain. What is the most probable clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing dilated clubbed calyces with stricture of the left ureteropelvic junction points to a diagnosis of hydronephrosis.

Hydronephrosis refers to the dilatation of the pelvicalyceal system caused by a partial or complete blockage of urinary flow. 

Investigations:

  • Ultrasound is the least invasive technique for diagnosing hydronephrosis.
  • Retrograde pyelography is rarely indicated but will confirm the site of obstruction before corrective surgery.
  • Intravenous urogram (IVU) is helpful only if the obstructed kidney is functional. In IVU, the extrarenal pelvis is dilated and the minor calyces lose their normal cupping. In early stages, there is blunting of calyces followed by its clubbing in the late stages.
  • A renal isotope scan (DTPA or MAG-3) is the best modality to confirm the obstructive dilatation of the collecting system.

Related Pearl: Causes of Hydronephrosis

Unilateral hydronephrosis

Extramural obstruction

  • Tumor from adjacent structures, e.g., cervix, prostate, rectum, colon, or cecum
  • Retrocaval ureter
  • Aberrant renal vessels
  • Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (Ormond’s disease)

Intramural obstruction

  • Congenital PUJ obstruction - most common congenital cause
  • Congenital stenosis
  • Ureterocele
  • Ureteric stricture - iatrogenic/ inflammatory
  • Neoplasm of the ureter or bladder involving the ureteric orifice

Intraluminal obstruction

  • Renal stones - most common acquired unilateral cause
  • Sloughed papilla in papillary necrosis (especially, in patients with diabetes, analgesic abuse, or sickle cell disease)

Bilateral hydronephrosis

Congenital

  • Posterior urethral valves (associated with pulmonary hypoplasia)
  • Urethral atresia
  • PUJ obstruction

Acquired     

  • Benign prostatic hypertrophy or carcinoma of the prostate
  • Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (Ormond's disease)
  • Postoperative bladder neck scarring
  • Urethral stricture
  • Phimosis

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: Which of the following types of renal cell carcinoma is characterized by multiple losses of entire chromosomes?
questions.solution:
Chromophobe type renal cell carcinomas (RCC) are uniquely associated with multiple losses of entire chromosomes, including chromosomes 1, 2, 6, 10, 13, 17, and 21. Thus, they show extreme hypodiploidy.

Related Pearl: Histologic subtypes of renal cell carcinoma

 Clear-cell type:

  • Most common type
  • Originates from proximal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by deletion of chromosomes 3p & 6p 
  • Associated with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease and tuberous sclerosis

Papillary type:

  • Originates from proximal/distal convoluted tubules
  • Caused by c-met mutation
  • Histology shows Psammoma bodies
  • Associated with hereditary papillary renal cell carcinoma
  • Micropapillary variant is associated with long term dialysis

Chromophobe type:

  • Best prognosis
  • Originates from intercalated cells of collecting duct
  • Caused by loss of multiple chromosomes (1, 2, 6, 10, 13) and extreme hypodiploidy
  • Associated with Birt-Hogg- Dubé syndrome
  • Histology shows plant-like cells/ resin like nucleus
  • Cytokeratin positive on IHC 

Collecting (Bellini duct) type:

  • Worst prognosis
  • Originates from collecting tubules
  • Caused by deletion of 1q & monosomy of multiple chromosomes

Medullary type:

  • Poor prognosis
  • Originates from distal nephron
  • Associated with sickle cell anemia

Note: Sarcomatoid change can occur infrequently in all types of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) and is an ominous feature.

questions.text: A patient with carcinoma in situ of the urinary bladder is posted for intravesical therapy. What is the strain of mycobacteria that will be used in this therapy?
questions.solution:
An attenuated strain of Mycobacterium bovis is used in intravesical BCG therapy.

Intravesical BCG is used for the treatment of non-invasive (no invasion into the muscle layer) urinary bladder tumors. It induces a strong local inflammatory response against the attenuated bacteria, which helps in the destruction of the tumor cells.

Option d: Mw vaccine for multibacillary leprosy patients and their contacts is extracted from Mycobacterium indicus pranii. It is also used as an adjunct to chemotherapy for category II tuberculosis.

questions.text: A 68- year-old patient presents with difficulty in initiating micturition. A DRE reveals an enlarged nodular prostate with adherent rectal mucosa. PSA was found to be 25 ng/ml and a biopsy result was suggestive of adenocarcinoma. Which of the following statements is false regarding his condition ?

choices.text: PSA is a not specific marker for the condition.
Gleason score correlates with the pathological stage
It is associated with decreased % free PSA
It arises from the transitional zone of the gland.

questions.solution:
Prostatic carcinoma, as indicated in the clinical scenario, arises from the peripheral zone of the gland.

Anatomically, the prostate is divided into three zones. 

  • The peripheral zone lies posteriorly and has an abundance of prostatic glands. 
  • The central zone lies posterior to the urethral lumen and above the seminal vesicles as they course through the prostate. 
  • The transitional zone is periurethral.

Benign prostatic hyperplasia arises from the transitional zone.

Gleason grading may be used after biopsy to evaluate the stage of histopathological specimen. Gleason scores range from 6 to 10 where 6 is low risk for prostate cancer while 10 is high risk.

PSA (prostatic specific antigen) is a glycoprotein peptidase that facilitates the liquefaction of semen. It is useful for screening and for monitoring response to therapy but is neither specific nor sensitive to the condition as it can be elevated due to old age and benign conditions such as prostatitis and BPH.

Slightly elevated total PSA (between 4.0 and 10.0 ng/mL) and low free PSA (<25%) is suspicious for prostate cancer.

questions.text: A newborn infant is diagnosed with a congenital urethral abnormality in which the urethral meatus opens on the ventral side of the penis. Which of the following statements regarding this condition is false?

choices.text: Circumcision is avoided in these patients
Dorsal aspect of the prepuce is poorly developed
Usually associated with a ventral deformity of the erect penis
Does not cause obstruction in the urinary tract

questions.solution:
The ventral aspect of the prepuce is poorly developed ("hooded prepuce") in hypospadias.

Hypospadias is the most common congenital abnormality of the urethra. It is characterized by the combination of a ventrally (underside of penis or perineum) placed urethral meatus, a hooded foreskin, and ventral chordee (bending of the penis).

Types of hypospadias (according to meatal location):

  • Anterior (Distal)
    • Glanular (most common)
    • Coronal
  • Middle
    • Middle penile shaft
    • Distal penile shaft
  • Posterior (Proximal)
    • Proximal penile shaft
    • Penoscrotal
    • Scrotal
    • Perineal

Note:

In hypospadias, ventral chordee is seen, whereas, in epispadias, dorsal chordee is seen.

Circumcision is contraindicated in hypospadias because the foreskin may be used later for reconstruction.

Hypospadias does not cause either obstruction or urinary tract infection.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding testicular tumors?

choices.text: They may present as an abdominal lump.
Testicular biopsy is done to diagnose testicular carcinoma.
Seminomas metastasize predominantly via the lymphatic system.
Elevated tumor markers are found almost exclusively in non-seminomatous germ-cell tumors.

questions.solution:
There is no role of testicular biopsy in the diagnosis of testicular tumors. This is due to the risk of seeding tumor cells onto the scrotal wall.

In testicular tumors, the most common site of lymphatic spread is retroperitoneal lymph nodes which may present as an abdominal lump. 

Elevated tumor markers are found almost exclusively in non-seminomatous germ-cell tumors.  Few seminomas may have elevated placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP) or beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG). Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) can be used as a marker of tumor bulk.

Seminomas are radiosensitive tumors that metastasize via lymphatics. Non-germ-cell tumors arise from Sertoli or Leydig cells and follow a more benign course. Approximately only 10% are malignant.

Related Pearl: Tumor Markers in Testicular Germ Cell Tumors

 

AFP

b-hCG

LDH

Seminoma

 -

+

++

Yolk sac tumor

+++

+

+

Choriocarcinoma

 -

+++

+

Embryonal carcinoma

+

+

++

Teratoma

 - 

 -

 -

 Note:

 Alpha-fetoprotein AFP: Raised in

  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Yolk sac tumor
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Mixed germ cell tumor

AFP is never raised in pure seminomas or pure choriocarcinoma

Human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG): Only the β subunit is measured by the most commonly available serum assays. Can be raised in

  • Choriocarcinoma
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Seminoma (only in about 15% Seminomas)
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH):

  • LDH has limited sensitivity and specificity for seminoma, but LDH levels >2000 U/L are more consistent with bulky disease, and rising levels are an accurate indicator of recurrence.
  •  In non-seminomatous germ-cell tumors (NSCGT), LDH is directly related to tumor burden.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient presented with a scrotal swelling. On examination, the testis is felt separate from the scrotal swelling and the swelling is brilliantly transilluminant, as shown in the image below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a transilluminant scrotal swelling palpated apart from normal testes is suggestive of an epididymal cyst. 

An epididymal cyst is a multilocular cyst formed due to is the cystic degeneration of the epididymis. Multiple cysts formed posterior to the epididymis can feel like a bunch of grapes on palpation. Due to the presence of crystal clear fluid, an epididymal cyst brilliantly transilluminates and has a Chinese lantern appearance.

The image shows the Chinese lantern appearance on transillumination:


It can be differentiated from a hydrocele, where the testis is not separately palpable.

Option A: Varicoceles present with dragging discomfort in the scrotum on standing and characteristic ‘bag of worms’ feel on palpation. 

Option C: Spermatocele is a unilocular transluminant retention cyst formed at the epididymal head. Due to the presence of spermatozoa, barley-water fluid is seen. Although transilluminant, the cyst does not have a Chinese lantern appearance.

Option D: Chyloceles are formed due to the rupture of lymphatic varix and the discharge of chyle into the hydrocele. Fluid rich in cholesterol is seen and the swelling is not transilluminant.

Related Pearl: Brilliantly Transilluminating Swellings

  • Vaginal hydrocele
  • Epididymal cyst
  • Cystic hygroma
  • Ranula
  • Meningocele

questions.text: A patient presented with pelvic fracture and membranous urethral rupture. What should be the initial management?

choices.text: A suprapubic catheter should be inserted as soon as possible

questions.solution:
The initial management should be insertion of suprapubic catheter.

A suprapubic catheter should be inserted as soon as practicable. The distended bladder may be palpable making suprapubic catheterization straightforward, but often the bruising and swelling associated with the fracture makes this difficult and ultrasound guidance is required.

Passing a catheter blindly per urethra may convert a partial tear into a complete tear and it may also lead to false passages.

A retrograde urethrogram should also be done as soon as possible to see the extent of the rupture.

questions.text:
Which of the following features are part of Reynold's pentad?

1. Altered mental status

2. Vomiting

3. Jaundice

4. Hypotension

5. Diaphoresis
questions.solution:
Vomiting and diaphoresis are not part of Reynold's pentad. Reynold's pentad is seen in acute suppurative cholangitis.

Related Pearl: Charcot and Reynold's Triad

Charcot's triad - in acute cholangitis

  • Right upper quadrant pain
  • Fever with chills
  • Jaundice

Reynold's pentad - in acute suppurative cholangitis

  • Charcot’s triad + Altered mental status + Hypotension

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for the condition shown below?
questions.solution:
The X-ray image shows calcification of the gallbladder, also known as porcelain gallbladder. This condition is associated with the risk of gall bladder carcinoma. Cholecystectomy is the treatment of choice.

Extended cholecystectomy includes removal of the gall bladder with a 2 cm non-anatomical wedge of the liver and lymphadenectomy. It is performed for stage Ib with perineural, lymphatic, vascular invasion, and stage II of gallbladder carcinoma.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female is on oral contraceptives. She presented with abdominal pain for the past few days. She was evaluated and was told that she is suffering from a liver disease. Which of the following liver disease is most likely to undergo haemorrhage ?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, hepatic adenoma  is most likely to cause haemorrhage.

These are benign liver tumors seen in women aged 25 and 50 years. The lesions are solitary, well-defined, and vascular. They are usually associated with the use of the oral contraceptive pill. 

They are found incidentally but can present in some cases with pain due to rupture or bleeding. They have malignant potential.

Large hepatic adenomas are at an increased risk of rupture and intraperitoneal hemorrhage.

Surgical excision is recommended if lesions are >5 cm.

Other options:

Option A: Focular nodular hyperplasia is a benign condition with an unknown etiology. It doesn't have any malignant potential and therefore there is no need for treatment or follow-up after confirming the diagnosis.

Option B: Hepatocellular carcinoma is one of the primary liver malignancies. Chronic hepatitis B infection and hepatitis C are considered risk factors. The cause of death in 60 percent of cases is related to cancer while the rest is due to an underlying pathology. Surgical resection is considered a treatment in patients with preserved liver function.

Option C: Hemangiomas are the most common liver lesions and they can rupture. Diagnosis is incidental and surgical resection is needed if the patient is significantly symptomatic or there is uncertainty in diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient with a pancreatic neoplasm undergoes cyst fluid aspiration. The aspirated fluid stains positive for mucin and shows elevated levels of amylase and CEA. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Positive mucin staining, elevated carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), and elevated amylase levels are seen in cases of intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN).

Cyst fluid analysis of various pancreatic cystic neoplasms:

Characteristics Serous cystic neoplasm (SCN) Mucinous cystic neoplasm (MCN) Intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm (IPMN)
Cytology

Scant glycogen-rich cells, with positive periodic acid–Schiff stain

Sheets and clusters of columnar, mucin-containing cells

Tall, columnar, mucin-containing cells
Mucin stain Negative Positive Positive
Amylase Low Low High
CEA Low High High

questions.text: A patient with liver cirrhosis is scheduled to undergo a laparotomy for a perforated appendix. According to the Child-Turcotte-Pugh score, which of the following parameters will you not use for this patient?
questions.solution:
Creatinine is not included in the Child–Turcotte–Pugh score or Child-Pugh scoring system. 

It is used to assess the surgical mortality of cirrhotic patients undergoing intra-abdominal operations.

Related Pearl: Child-Turcotte-Pugh Score

The Child–Turcotte–Pugh (CTP) score was originally developed to evaluate the risk of portocaval shunt procedures performed for portal hypertension. It is also useful in predicting the surgical risks of other intra-abdominal operations performed in cirrhotic patients.

Variable

1 Point

2 Points

3 Points

Bilirubin level

<2 mg/dL

2–3 mg/dL

>3 mg/dL

Albumin level

>3.5 g/dL

2.8–3.5 g/dL

<2.8 g/dL

1–3

<1.7

4–6

1.7–2.3

>6

>2.3

Encephalopathy

None

Controlled

Uncontrolled

Child-Turcotte-Pugh class and overall surgical mortality rates:

  • Class A = 5–6 points - Well-compensated - 10% mortality
  • Class B = 7–9 points - Decompensated and significant  functional compromise - 30% mortality
  • Class C = 10–15 points - Severerly decompensated - 75-80% mortality

Prognosis of the various CTP classes:

Class 1-year survival rate  % 2-year survival rate %
A 100 85
B 80 60
C 45 35

questions.text: MEN 2A is associated with all except:
questions.solution:
Pancreatic tumours are not a feature of  MEN 2 A.

MEN Syndromes:

MEN 2A includes MPH:

  • Medullary thyroid cancer
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Hyperparathyroidism

Medullary carcinoma thyroid plays the key role in MEN 2.

MEN 2 is due to germline mutation in RET proto oncogene in chromosome 10.

Pheochromocytoma is usually bilateral in MEN 2a.

questions.text: Most common thyroid malignancy arising from thyroglossal cyst:
questions.solution:
Most common cancer arising from a thyroglossal cyst is Papillary carcinoma.

Approximately 1% of thyroglossal duct cysts are found to be malignant of which the most common type of cancer is papillary (85%). Medullary thyroid carcinomas are not found in thyroglossal duct cysts.

However, the most common complication of Thyroglossal cyst is infection.

questions.text: Follicular carcinoma of thyroid is due to the mutation of?
questions.solution:
Genes implicated in the pathogenesis of Follicular Thyroid Cancers:

  • p53
  • PTEN
  • Ras
  • PAX8/PPAR1

 

Related Pearl: Follicular thyroid malignancy

It is more common in iodine-deficient areas. It is associated with p53, PTEN, PAX/PPAR-gamma, RAS, miRNA (miR-197 and miR-346).

It commonly presents as solitary thyroid nodules and the mean age of presentation is 50 years. It can also occur in long-standing cases of multinodular goitre.

FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions as malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion. Hence, Trucut biopsy is required to confirm malignancy.

Histological findings:

  • Encapsulated
  • Uniform microfollicles or sheets of cells devoid of colloid
  • Capsular and vascular invasion indicates malignancy
  • Tumour thrombus within middle thyroid/ jugular veins may be seen at the time of surgery

Vascular (hematogenous) dissemination is common, with metastases to bone, lungs, liver, and elsewhere. The prognosis depends largely on the extent of invasion and stage at presentation.

Serum thyroglobulin levels are used for monitoring tumour recurrence, as they are undetectable after complete treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site of ectopic parathyroid gland?
questions.solution:
The most common site of the ectopic parathyroid gland is paraesophageal.

The common sites of ectopic parathyroid glands are

  • Paraesophageal - most common
  • Mediastinal 
  • Intrathymic 
  • Intrathyroidal 
  • Carotid sheath 
  • High cervical or undescended 

Ectopic parathyroid is the most common cause of persistent or recurrent hyperparathyroidism. In such cases, treatment involves surgical removal of the gland.

questions.text: A young man presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominal pain and 3 episodes of vomiting in the past 9 hours. He says that the pain radiates to the back and is partially relieved by bending forwards. The abdominal radiograph of the patient is given below. What is the sign that is seen in the radiograph?
questions.solution:
The image shows the colon cut-off sign, which is seen in acute pancreatitis.

The colon cut-off sign refers to the abrupt termination of the gas filling of the colon on the left side. The inflammation of acute pancreatitis may extend to the phrenicocolic ligament via the transverse mesocolon. This causes functional spasm of the splenic flexure resulting in the colon cut-off sign.

All the other options mentioned above are also seen in acute pancreatitis.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in Acute Pancreatitis

Radiographic findings of acute pancreatitis are non-specific.

The sentinel loop is seen in an X-ray. It is a focal area of adynamic ileus close to an intra-abdominal inflammatory process. A sentinel loop in the upper abdomen indicates pancreatitis.

The sentinel loop sign may aid in localizing the source of inflammation. For example, a sentinel loop in the upper abdomen may indicate pancreatitis, while one in the right lower quadrant may be due to appendicitis.

Colon cut-off sign: Functional spasm at the splenic flexure due to the extension of inflammation to phrenicocolic ligament via transverse mesocolon.

The X-ray given below shows sentinel loop sign (marked as '1') and colon cut-off sign (marked as '2') in a patient with acute pancreatitis:

 

Renal halo sign: Edema around the kidney due to the involvement of paranephric fat resulting in:

  • Obliteration of psoas shadow
  • Localised ground-glass appearance

questions.text:
Which of the following will you not add as part of the chemotherapeutic regime for a patient with breast cancer?
  1. Cyclophosphamide
  2. Fludarabine
  3. Adriamycin
  4. Paclitaxel
  5. Vincristine
questions.solution:
Fludarabine and vincristine are not used in chemotherapy for carcinoma breast.

The present chemotherapy regimen used is ACT regimen, i.e., adriamycin, cyclophosphamide, and taxane (paclitaxel). It comprises 4 cycles of AC followed by 4 cycles of T.

Earlier regimens that are less commonly used currently are as follows:

  • CAF – Cyclophosphamide, Adriamycin, 5-Fluorouracil
  • CMF – Cyclophosphamide, Methotrexate, 5-Fluorouracil

Indications for chemotherapy in carcinoma breast:

  • Lymph nodes positive
  • Lymph nodes negative but tumor size of >1 cm
  • Lymph nodes negative and tumor size of >0.5 cm with
    1. Blood vessel/Lymph vessel invasion
    2. ER/PR –ve
    3. Her-2/neu overexpression
    4. High grade
  • Triple-negative breast carcinoma
  • High recurrence score after Oncotype Dx.

Sacituzumab Govitecan-hziy, a Trop-2-directed antibody and topoisomerase inhibitor drug conjugate recently approved by the FDA for the treatment of adult patients with metastatic triple-negative breast cancer who have received at least two prior therapies.
